node.title: some errors when installing moose
node.bodyText:
Hello, my computer encounter a installing problem, could anybody help?
I notice that you guys update the method of installing moose by "conda -n moose ..", but this method does not work in my computer. I installed the moose by the old way successfully in my another computer, so I installed the software by the old way through mamba command "mamba create -n moose moose-tools moose-libmesh"，this way works.
And I git clone the moose from github through command:
"mkdir -p ~/projects
cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master"

These are ok.
But when i make and test the software:"cd ~/projects/moose/test, make -j 4"，the terminal shows error:
"Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory,
or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install
make: *** [/home/guohejie/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:371: wasp_submodule_status] Error 1"

and then I run the command:"scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh" this seems also work.
but when I make the test:"make -j 4"
some errors occur:
"Creating Unity /home/guohejie/projects/moose/test/build/unity_src/actions_Unity.C
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/guohejie/projects/moose/test/build/unity_src/auxkernels_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/guohejie/projects/moose/test/build/unity_src/bcs_Unity.C...
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/lib/libsuperlu_dist.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_loop_nonmonotonic_guided_start@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/libmesh/lib/libmesh_opt.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_loop_nonmonotonic_dynamic_start@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/lib/libstrumpack.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_taskloop_ull@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/lib/libstrumpack.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_loop_ull_nonmonotonic_dynamic_next@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/libmesh/lib/libmesh_opt.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_loop_nonmonotonic_dynamic_next@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/lib/libsuperlu_dist.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_loop_nonmonotonic_guided_next@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/lib/libstrumpack.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_taskloop@GOMP_4.5'
/home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/guohejie/mambaforge3/envs                                    /moose/lib/libstrumpack.so: undefined reference to `GOMP_loop_ull_nonmonotonic_dynamic_start@GOMP_4.5'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status"
It seems like you have a problem in your environment related to the threading library. What is the output of mamba list?

These should all be strictly conda-forge supplied packages, except the few from our channel. While this may not be a 100% requirement, it is odd. This suggests you have multiple channels (conda-forge, anaconda base perhaps, and of course our Idaholab channel).
As well as the /usr/local/ stuff. Which suggests a custom installation of what appears to be a GNU compiler (of perhaps only Fortran).
Our Conda Packages were built explicitly using Fortran available from Conda:
gfortran_impl_linux-64    10.4.0              h7d168d2_19    conda-forge
gfortran_linux-64         10.4.0              h69d5af5_13    conda-forge

Which is why the above is being installed in your Conda environment when you install moose-dev. To have other 'compilers' lying around is what usually causes issues like the ones you are seeing.
Because we have no idea why you have compilers in your /usr/local area, we can't ask you to delete them. Meaning: the only proper solution here, is for you to continue using those compilers in /usr/local, and not use Conda at all. You will need to instead build your compiler stack from scratch (you need to add GCC, and an MPI wrapper to your host of applications already in /usr/local). Basically, you must have only one compiler stack present in your environment (/usr/local is checked by default for binaries and libraries. So by having items in this location, these items will always be present in your environment).

Yes, I usually use anaconda to do some python coding work which include some other packages. This should not be the problem in my opinion, because my another computer which is ok for installing moose also installed anaconda. I will try as your suggestions, thank you for your help.

You might benefit from adding strict channel priority: conda config --set channel_priority strict.
Indeed, reading the documentation, this feature looks to be slated to be default set in Conda 5.0 in the future. Ref: https://conda-forge.org/docs/user/introduction.html

node.title: how to provide additional field (material, auxvariable or function) being read from csv-files, so that another matprop can depend on this field
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose users,
I am posting this question in general section, as this is a conceptual question, despite I want to apply this for a PorousFlow problem:
I want to make certain material properties like permeability and porosity depend on an additional „field“, here damage. That damage is provided at elements via csv (at elCentroids for now, but elQP data could be provided as well). I understand that I will subclass from one of the existing PorousFlowPermeabilityXXXX classes, but

I am struggling with the moose concept, whether that damage field should be another material property, an AuxVariable, or a PiecewiseLinearFunction? Does it make any difference, or is one way better than the other?

Now, reading this element data from csv, I think the userobject-class ReadPropertyFile will be appropriate, but I expect the damage field to change each timestep (remaining constant in time for that timestep, but changes at begin of next timestep). So i am providing many (dozens of) csv files, like damage0001.csv, damage0002.csv, etc.

do i need to declare as many userobject-objects of type=ReadPropertyFile, one for each csv? Then, one might use the control logic to enable the appropriate reader-object for a certain timestep, but how does the damage field, that my material property depends on, link to get data from the activated reader-object but not from the others? I see a potential shared interest as discussed in #25953, but my problem is still a bit different.

Many thanks for helping me find the right direction,

hello



Yes there is a difference between the three.
a) As a material property:

the additional field will be stored with a negligible memory cost, as material properties are computed on a per-element basis for every quadrature point.
the matprop will be constantly updated, on linear iterations
you can propagate derivatives with regards to the variable when using automatic differentiation. This is important if you are solving for this extra damage field as well.
b) As an auxvariable
the field will be computed once using an initial condition or an auxkernel, then only updated with auxkernels if needed on the execute_on specified in the input
the quadrature point values are obtained by evaluating the shape functions for the finite element family you use for that variable
derivatives are lost if you are trying to use AD
c) as a function
the field must only depend on space and time. Any other use (depend on variables) is a little hacky
the function is evaluated on-the-fly at quadrature points, so the information is always up-to-date, even though it's mostly constant for a time step

Since you are planning to use a UserObject to read the data from a CSV, I believe you can use:

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseConstantFromCSV.html
and maybe there is a material property in PorousFlow that already does it.

Unfortunately, yes for 2. PropertyReadFile should and will one day support multiple CSV files for each time step. But for now the only thing implemented is a single CSV file. Then turning on/off functions with controls will not work, because functions are referenced by their name and the name is unique.
However you can turn on/off with controls both auxkernels and materials (less sure for that second one but please let me know if you try it)
So if you used an auxkernel with let's say 10 CSV files for ten time steps you need:

10 PropertyReadFile to read each file
10 functions PiecewiseConstrantFromCSV, one for each UO
10 auxkernels FunctionAux that set the SAME auxvariable damage using a different function
10 Controls objects that turn on/off the auxkernels on each time step

I agree this is not idea. It's either that or implementing support for multiple files in PropertyReadFile. We have a feature request iirc, just no one to work on it
Guillaume

Thank you Guillaume, for your detailed answer!
Just one follow-up question on this: Do you know, if all the PropertyReadFile objects (as 10 UOs for 10 csv-files) do read these csv files all at the beginning of the analysis, or, more ideal, read them just when the control enables the specific UO?
The latter would be ideal to both to (i) reduce time to setup before calculation starts and potentially reduce memory needed to store just one csv-field instead of all csv-fields, as well as to (ii) have the option to get the csv-files provided by an external process while the moose job is already running. Thanks!
Arnd

They read them at construction time, not at activation time.
See the call to   readData(); in the constructor.
I can see the new for both (i) and (ii). I dont think it would be too much work to move this call to initialSetup() instead or even later if you want to try

@arndflatten I realized building 10 functions was not how we wanted to do this in MOOSE so I gave a try a specifying multiple CSV files to a single reader, and one is read every execution of the object (either every time step or using Controls)
see this PR #26395 if you want to try it out

and _current_file_index(declareRestartableData<unsigned int>("file_index", 0)),
is there a way that I can control _current_file_index from input file?

node.title: Some questions about peacock
node.bodyText:
I am trying to use MOOSE. This afternoon, I just successfully used the peacock to check my mesh file's boundaries. But now,I can not open it.
I use the peacock following the official website。First，I use “mamba activate peacock", and then use "peacock",but it only tell me "Segmentation fault (core  dumped)"
Thank you for all the answers.
If there is any other way to check the boundaries IDs in the MOOSE it can also help.

I recall this issue may be related to the underlying application no longer able to launch. Can you enter your 'moose' environment and perform a mamba list:
mamba deactivate
mamba activate moose
mamba list
Next, I'd like to run the actual app, see if that works:
cd ~/projects/moose/modules/heat_conduction
./heat_conduction-opt --dump
You don't have to report everything this command prints out (its a lot). All I am after, is if this command succeeds or fails in some way. Peacock runs the above command to produce the Input parameters available to display. If it fails, I can see Peacock seg faulting.
Also, regardless what happens, the next thing I want you to try is to delete head_conduction-opt, and then run Peacock. Without a binary, Peacock will be forced to just "load up". And this would simply test that the issue not exactly a Peacock-only one.
cd ~/projects/moose/modules/heat_conduction
rm heat_conduction-opt 
mamba deactivate
mamba activate peacock
peacock
Also, if you can, please paste the text of the above output, instead of a screen shot of text. It help to use text instead so "searches" among our Discussions pages actually produce real results for others to find, if in the event they are running into the same error as you.

node.title: Peacock will not Run
node.bodyText:
When I attempt to run peacock by calling just peacock I get the following error
peacock: command not found
When I attempt to run peacock from the relevant directory by using ../../../../python/peacock/peacock I get the following error:
Error starting peacock: Could not import vtk
You may need to either create or load an environment providing PyQt, VTK, etc.
The MOOSE development team provides a conda package with the required dependencies:
    mamba create -n peacock moose-peacock python=3.10
    mamba activate peacock

Then run peacock again
I am attempting to run peacock from the environment it attempts to set up. Any idea what I am doing wrong?
Thanks!

Hello
To just run peacock from anywhere, you need to add the peacock folder to your PATH environment variable.
To run peacock, you need to follow these instructions that the error gives you
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I have followed the instructions the error gave and set up the peacock environment - even within the peacock environment that error appears.
I added peacock to my path variable, and am still getting the following error:
Error starting peacock: Could not import vtk
You may need to either create or load an environment providing PyQt, VTK, etc.
The MOOSE development team provides a conda package with the required dependencies:
    mamba create -n peacock moose-peacock python=3.10
    mamba activate peacock

Then run peacock again
Note that I am running this peacock environment as the error message said to set it up.
Thanks!

moose-peacock should come with VTK... interesting!
Can you perform the following:
mamba activate peacock
mamba list
I would like to see what moose-peacock actually installed.

Oooo... trame-vtk. Right. That should work. But I am finding issues with it myself. Apologies for this (I am the one responsible for this package).
This is a temporary fix, until I get that package squared away. Can you perform the following:
mamba deactivate
mamba env remove -n peacock
mamba create -n peacock python=3.10 pandas pyqt matplotlib vtk
mamba activate peacock
...and then attempt to use Peacock.

The computer attempts to run peacock, then I get the message Aborted
Edit: Looking through some of your old message boards, I am using Ubuntu on a Windows Machine

There are a number of other threads where this combination/situation, is not working correctly. My own personal Windows 10 machine works at home, and... I don't know why.
Can you try an older version?
mamba deactivate
mamba env remove -n peacock
mamba create -n peacock moose-peacock=2022.12.05
mamba activate peacock
I believe this was the last version that I remember working in WSL. As in, this ref thread: #22718 (reply in thread)
I'm getting the Aborted error message again.

This is not going to be a Conda issue then. This is going to be either a VcXsrv configuration issue, or something with Windows 'blocking' the Display port perhaps.
Can you run the following?
mamba deactivate
mamba create -n paraview paraview
mamba activate paraview
paraview
It might take a while to pop up, but this is a product that uses much of the same dependencies as Peacock, but is not Peacock. Its a good test to make sure, its not something strange with our Peacock package.
Also, does xeyes work? Or some other graphical Linux binary? xeyes is super simple. It doesn't use any VTK acceleration (where much of our issues usually derive from), but it useful to prove that your DISPLAY= and VcXsrc is properly setup.

Hello! Sorry for the late reply. You were right, it does seem I had some issues with VcXsrv. I know this isn't MOOSE-related, but it ended up being a firewall issue. I thought I might just drop the link for the setup guide I ended up using to change permissions for future reference.
Thank you so much for all your help :)
https://www.shogan.co.uk/how-tos/wsl2-gui-x-server-using-vcxsrv/
I am glad you figured it out! Thank you for posting that link! Very helpful... I'll likely refer to this discussion in the future :)

node.title: having problem to start peacock
node.bodyText:
I am using mac system and following the instruction on https://mooseframework.inl.gov/python/peacock.html for peacock.
In the environmenpart part, I created a bash_profile and put:
export PATH=/Users/xuke/projects/moose/python/peacock:$PATH
in bash_profile.
And i want to try the example in moose, so i did
(peacock) xuke@xukedeMac-mini ~ % cd ~/projects/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
(peacock) xuke@xukedeMac-mini ex01_inputfile % peacock
zsh: command not found: peacock

I also tried this but still did not work
(peacock) xuke@xukedeMac-mini gui % pwd                                   
/Users/xuke/projects/moose/gui
(peacock) xuke@xukedeMac-mini gui % peacock
zsh: command not found: peacock


Here is the files in gui folder
(base) xuke@xukedeMac-mini gui % ls
BasePeacockMainWindow.py	PostprocessorViewer
CheckRequirements.py		PythonConsoleWidget.py
Execute				__init__.py
ExodusViewer			__pycache__
Input				base
LogWidget.py			icons
PeacockApp.py			peacock
PeacockException.py		tests
PeacockMainWindow.py		utils

I am unclear what to do to run peacock. Thanks for helping.

zsh: command not found: peacock
^^^ means you are using ZSH and not BASH

You need to instead modify your ~/.zshrc profile.
Edit: Those instructions are dated... we need to add ~/.zshrc
Issue created: #25818

Oh my... those instructions are very dated. You no longer need to operate in a separate peacock environment. If you have installed the latest moose-dev, this includes moose-peacock. If you would, please exit that peacock environment, and delete it :). You can safely use peacock while in the (moose) environment.
A little history:
The reason they were separated before, was due to all the dependencies involved were causing conflicts with the toolchain being installed with moose-mpich. This was remedied not to long ago with version moose-dev=2023.09.19.
Thank you so much for helping. I can run peacock now.

Hello sir I'm facing issue with peacock gui
The error is "Segmentation fault(core dumped)"
When try simply peacock command.
I have successfully installed the Moose update path done everything.

node.title: How to couple subapp and masterapp with different timescales?
node.bodyText: for example, the timescale of subapp is 0.1s (time 1 in MOOSE has the unit 0.1s), but the main app is slower (time 1 in MOOSE has the unit 0.01s). The two apps are transient apps. How to couple them with a multiapp system?

Hello
See these slides for the various time stepping options during coupling
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/presentation/index.html#/2/10
Guillaume

Thank you, but I think you mean using sub_cycling to let the main app and the sub app have different time steps during the iteration. And what I'm asking is how to couple the main app and the sub app when they represent physics that are not as fast as each other (they have different time unit).

Should you be solving one to steady state every time you want to couple them at a timestep of the other then?
Use a fullsolvemultiapp instead of a transientmultiapp for that
